Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Exploring Human Centered and Socially Relevant Interactive Technologies in Computer Vision, Visualization, Pervasive Computing, Serious Games, and Social Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of the REU Site at UNC Charlotte is to implement effective practices to engage a diverse
group of undergraduate students in computing research. Undergraduate students will actively pursue
research that applies human-computer interaction (HCI) concepts to advance the state of the art in a
particular field, including pervasive computing, computer vision, data visualization, social networks, and
serious games. Each research project has a socially relevant theme, providing students with the
opportunity to apply and extend their computing knowledge to address problems that have a real-world
impact. The site emphasizes participation of promising students from underrepresented groups in
computing and from institutions that have limited research programs. To help students become rapidly
immersed in the culture of research and to prepare them for meaningful research experiences, the site
cultivates an authentic community of practice that values the contributions of REU students as
researchers, and provides REU participants with explicit, just-in-time training in research skills at a
weekly workshop.

The intellectual merit of this project lies in the REU students? contributions to the discovery and
evaluation of innovative, interactive computing solutions to address problems of interest in society;
specific projects may address open problems in the fields of computer vision, pervasive computing, data
visualization, social networks, and serious games. The broader impact of this project lies in the
opportunity to introduce talented students from underrepresented populations to computing research and
in the potential to increase the enrollment of domestic students in doctoral computing programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Socially Relevant Computing REU Site at UNC Charlotte supports 10 undergraduate students each summer in intensive 9-week research experiences. Undergraduate students actively pursue research that applies human­ computer interaction (HCI) concepts to advance the state of the art in a particular field, including pervasive computing, computer vision, data visualization, social networks, and serious games, with each research project centered on a socially relevant theme. These research projects provide students with the opportunity to apply and extend their computing knowledge to address problems that have a real-­world impact. The Site cultivates an authentic community of practice that values the contributions of a diverse group of REU students as effective computing researchers. Participants develop their research abilities through weekly seminars that are designed to establish a common foundation for research methods and technical skills in socially relevant computing research. These meetings feature expert speakers or interactive panels with current graduate students and REU program alumni to provide information about graduate school, fellowships, and career opportunities. As part of the seminar, REU students complete an online training course on ethical human subjects research  that provide training in research skills so that students are supported and prepared for rapid immersion in the research culture and for meaningful experiences.

In addition to conducting research, REU Site students learn to communicate the significance of their research problem, approach, and results. Our REU Site is the co-founder of the Southeast Regional REU Site Mini­-conference, a one day event that brings together faculty, graduate student mentors, and REU Site students from the region to help them to gain experience in communicating the value of research results, develop a network of students and faculty interested in research, to gain exposure to several research topics, and to see broader opportunities for pursuing graduate study. The Socially Relevant Computing REU students present flash talks and participate in a poster session at the mini-conference at the program midpoint. They also give a formal presentation of their final results at the annual UNC Charlotte College of Computing and Informatics Summer Undergraduate Research Symposium; a panel of faculty judge the talks for technical merit, significance of the student’s contribution to the research project, and clarity of presentation, awarding prizes for the top three talks. The REU Site students are also encouraged to work with their research mentors publish their research work; since 2012, participants in the Socially Relevant Computing REU Site have published over 24 student co-authored articles in peer reviewed venues. 

The Socially Relevant Computing REU Site has demonstrated a commitment to broadening participation of promising students from underrepresented groups in computing and from institutions that have limited research programs. Women represented 56% (27/48) of our participants and underrepresented minority students represented 25% (12/48) of our participants, compared to 28% and13% (respectively) nationwide. Our Site also emphasized participation of students with limited research opportunities; 60% (29/48) of our participants were from institutions that do not have doctoral research programs.  

With respect to improving the performance and skills of students, we have found that the tiered mentoring approach we employ in our program is valued by the REU students and is also effective in providing graduate students with the opportunity to develop their research project management skills by assisting the undergraduate students in their summer projects. A comparison of pre­- and post-­surveys show statistically significant gains for REU students in computing self-­efficacy, and increases in help­-seeking skills, research skills, identity as a computing professional, and scientific leadership skills.
